entry.title: ByeTools is getting Undertale support (and I guess this is the first time I’ve ever mentioned it)!

link.title: ByeTools is getting Undertale support (and I guess this is the first time I’ve ever mentioned it)!

entry.content:
So, recently I decieded to start playing Undertale, and after about two hours(!) I decided to change up my save game. Unfortunatly, Annoying Dog had other ideas.

So, what about stopping this? There is a tool called UndertaleSandbox that can do this, but I find it restrictive and hard to use. How about rephrasing the question to “So, what can I do about stopping this?”

I’ll keep you updated.

ByeTools x Undertale series:

  1. ByeTools is getting Undertale support (and I guess this is the first time I’ve ever mentioned it)! [YOU ARE HERE]

This project IS NOT OFFICIAL OR ENDORSED BY Toby Fox OR ANYONE ELSE ASSOCIATED WITH Undertale
entry.summary: So, recently I decieded to start playing Undertale, and after about two hours(!) I decided to change up my save game. Unfortunatly, Annoying Dog had other ideas.

entry.title: How I Got This To Work

link.title: How I Got This To Work

entry.content:
Hello, and welcome to my brand-new, revamped website! Using GitHub Pages, I’ve been hosting a small website for the last few months. However, I’ve been wanting to start a blog. For this, I’m going to use Jekyll. Jekyll lets you make dynamic websites. It’s mainly used as a blogging tool, and Pages has internal support for it.

This site uses a theme called Chirpy, but GitHub Pages does not have support for more than a couple themes. So this is how I made a workaround

The tree for this site really looks like this:

Z:\Websites\byemc.github.io>tree
Folder PATH listing for volume ProgrammingAndGames
Volume serial number is 1068-94FE
Z:.
├───.jekyll-cache
│   └───Jekyll
│       └──[...]
│               └───fe
├───assets
│   ├───css
│   ├───img
│   └───js
├───docs
├───gulpfile.js
│   └───tasks
├───stuff
│   ├───.github
│   └───old
├───tools
├───_data
├───_includes
├───_javascript
├───_layouts
├───_plugins
├───_posts
├───_sass
├───_site
│   ├───about
│   ├───archives
│   ├───assets
│   ├───categories
│   ├───norobots
│   ├───posts
│   │   └───how-i-got-this-to-work
│   ├───stuff
│   │   └───old
│   └───tags
└───_tabs

Z:\Websites\byemc.github.io>▮

But GitHub sees this:

Z:\Websites\byemc.github.io\_site>tree
Folder PATH listing for volume ProgrammingAndGames
Volume serial number is 1068-94FE
Z:.
├───about
├───archives
├───assets
│   ├───css
│   ├───img
│   │   └───favicons
│   └───js
│       ├───data
│       ├───dist
│       └───lib
├───categories
├───norobots
├───posts
│   └───how-i-got-this-to-work
├───stuff
│   └───old
│       ├───shit
│       ├───spark
│       ├───webmaker
│       └───websitemaker
└───tags
    ├───github-pages
    └───tech

Z:\Websites\byemc.github.io\_site>

Why is this so? It’s simply because I put the .git folder in _site, which means that Git (the program that GitHub runs on).

Unsatisfactory ending to something noone cares about. You’re welcome (^///^)
entry.summary: Hello, and welcome to my brand-new, revamped website! Using GitHub Pages, I’ve been hosting a small website for the last few months. However, I’ve been wanting to start a blog. For this, I’m going to use Jekyll. Jekyll lets you make dynamic websites. It’s mainly used as a blogging tool, and Pages has internal support for it.
